Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Growth of the Tibetan Plateau and Eastern Asia Climate: Clues to Understanding the Hydrological Cycle
Award.AbstractNarration:
For fifty years, the Tibetan Plateau has been recognized as the largest topographic feature that perturbs atmospheric circulation. It serves as an ideal field laboratory for understanding the geodynamic processes that build high terrain. Accordingly, the growth of the plateau should have altered atmospheric circulation and therefore written an evolving paleoclimatic signature not only on eastern Asian regional climates, but on global climate as well. Despite many recent studies, we still do not know precisely when the Tibetan Plateau reached its current dimensions and how it perturbs atmospheric circulation. This project brings together geodynamicists, atmospheric scientists, and paleoclimatologists in a multidisciplinary study of the when and the how.

One of the major goals of the project is to quantify the extent to which Tibet has grown by crustal thickening, by thrust faulting and folding, by flow within the crust that redistributes material there, or by replacement of cold mantle lithosphere with hotter material (all in a state of isostatic equilibrium). Such quantification will take big steps toward the understanding of how high plateaus are built and how continental lithosphere deforms, topics at the forefront of geodynamics.

Determining how Tibet has grown will require determining when crustal shortening and thickening occurred, using basic field methods and modern laboratory techniques, and quantifying paleoaltitudes with new isotopic tools. Applying such paleoaltimetric techniques, however, requires an understanding not only of how the atmosphere transports isotopes, but how the evolving high terrain affected surface temperatures at times in the past.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Proposal: Growth of Tibetan Plateau and Eastern Asia Climate: Clues to Understanding the Hydrological Cycle.

Zhengyu Liu and J. Kutzbach

University of Wisconsin-Madison

This project has improved our understanding of the climate response of East Asia monsoon and hydrological cycle. First, we have proposed an explanation for the climate implication of he cave d18O records in East Asia: The d18O records are proposed now to be linked dynaically to the downstream rainfall in North China through the increased moisture transport, but is linked isotopically to the rainfall depletion upstream over the South Asia and Indian Ocean. This interpretation reconcides the seemingly contradictory results between current modeling and observations. Secondly, we have made a major advance in understanding the temporal slope of d18O-teperature relation in the high latitude. Confirmed by two isotope enabled atmospheric models, a semi-theoretical equation is proposed to relate the spatial and temporal slopes. This understanding could provide a guideline for understanding the isotope evoution over Tibetean Plateau, which is considered the third pole. Third, we have resolved a contradiction regarding the relation between summer and winter monsoons in the East Asia. We show that the summer and winter monsoons are positively correlated at orbital time scales as a response to precessional forcing, but negatively correlated at millennial time scales as a response to Atlantic Meridonal Overturning Circulation variability.

 

In addition,  we have studied other problems related to Asian monsoon and climate dynamics. We have studied the importance of winter rainfall for the interpretation of the hydrological respone and isotopic respone in the Mediterranean region and Central Asia. We have studied the impact of Tibet uplift on d18O distribution for the present and Last Glacial Maximum conditions. We have collaborated with Prof Haijun Yang (Pekiing University) in exploring the role of Tibetean Uplift on global thermohaline circulation. Our experiments show that Tibet exerts a major impact on the North Atlantic climate through atmosheric teleconnection and the amplfication by sea ice albedo feedback. We have studied the response of Hadley circulation to different SST and orbital forcing. Finally, we have been testing two hypotheses on the role of Tibetean Plateau on East Asia summer monsoon regarding the wind convergence response and eastward influence response.
